newsitem.title: USA: U.S. warns Turkish army to respect constitution.
newsitem.headline: U.S. warns Turkish army to respect constitution.

text.p: The United States fired a shot across the bows of the Turkish military on Friday, warning army leaders against "extra-constitutional" attempts to combat growing Islamic influence in Turkey.
But Secretary of State Madeleine Albright also reaffirmed strong U.S. support for a secular system in Turkey, the goal to which Turkish military leaders say they are attached.

Turkey's chief of military intelligence, Gen. Fevzi Turkeri, urged Turks on Wednesday to fight the danger of Islamic activism and said the army's role was to protect the country "by force of arms" from domestic and external threats.
"We obviously are watching and have been watching the situation very carefully," Albright told reporters before talks with Latvian Foreign Minister Valdis Birkavs.
"We have made very clear that it is essential that Turkey continue in a secular, democratic way," she said.

"We have also made clear that it's very important that whatever issues are going on there, whatever discussions and whatever changes people are thinking about, that they have to be within a democratic context and with no extra-constitutional approach."
But Albright added: "We appreciate the way that Turkey has in fact been a secular democracy."
Turkey has an Islamic-led government under Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan. But the administration, riven by internal dissent, appears close to collapse.
Erbakan has said he will step down in favour of his conservative coalition partner Tansu Ciller, perhaps as early as next week, and go for snap elections.

While continuing to hail Turkey as a valued NATO ally, Washington has viewed Erbakan with thinly disguised distaste, especially since he visited Libya last year. Officials make clear in private a strong preference for Ciller.
But Turkeri's remarks, which received major coverage Friday in the New York Times and Washington Post, appear to have raised fears in Washington of another military intervention in Turkish politics.
State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said Albright had chosen her words carefully at what he called "a very difficult time for Turkey."

"I think it's prudent for us to remind everyone at a time like this that the basis of Turkey's success as a country in the last decade or so has been its democratic tradition and its secular tradition," he added.
"Certainly, the military has a role to play in Turkish political life, if you look at the Turkish constitution and look at Turkish history," Burns said.
But, he said: "We believe that the democratic institutions of Turkey ought to be allowed to function according to the Turkish constitution. We are confident that will take place."

Burns said Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott had dicussed the Turkish military's role in political life with Gen. Cevik Bir, second-in-command of the armed forces, and political leaders during a visit to Ankara this month.
